description: Late Middle English, from Latin barbarus (“foreigner, savage”), from Ancient Greek βάρβαρος (bárbaros, “foreign, strange”).

adjectives.description: barbarous (comparative more barbarous, superlative most barbarous)

entries.meaning: (said of language) Not classical or pure.

examples: I felt vaguely he was a sneak, and remained quite unmollified by advances on his side, which, in a boy's barbarous fashion, unless it suited me to be magnanimous, I haughtily ignored.

entries.meaning: Mercilessly or impudently violent or cruel, savage.
Like a barbarian, especially in sound; noisy, dissonant.
examples: I did but prompt the age to quit their cloggsBy the known rules of antient libertie,When strait a barbarous noise environs meOf Owles and Cuckoes, Asses, Apes and Doggs
